channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Central Banks Raise Interest Rates, Fearing Worse Pain Later
item.description: Federal Reserve officials and their counterparts around the world are trying to defeat inflation by rapidly raising interest rates. They know it will come at a cost.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers at a food bank in London. The Bank of England on Thursday raised interest rates by half a point to 2.25 percent, even as it said that the United Kingdom might already be in a recession.

item.title: Pandemic Unemployment Fraud Estimate Rises to $45.6 Billion
item.description: A federal watchdog tripled its earlier estimate of benefits that the U.S. government paid to people who weren’t entitled to them.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi

item.title: Ukraine War Comes to Russia as Putin Imposes Draft
item.description: As Vladimir Putin’s “special military operation” enters a new chapter, Russians are being plucked from villages around the country for training and military service.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina

item.title: Russian Men, Fearing Ukraine Draft, Seek Refuge Abroad
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s new military call-up has sent young men who don’t want to fight in Ukraine heading to the borders.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Istanbul International Airport. With the government replenishing its military in Ukraine, some Russian men have headed for the borders.

item.title: As Trump’s Legal Woes Mount, So Do Financial Pressures on Him
item.description: The lawsuit filed by New York’s attorney general is the latest indication of how an array of investigations is affecting the former president’s business and personal wealth.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess, Matthew Goldstein and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Todd Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The numerous investigations and lawsuits swirling around former President Donald J. Trump are creating new and significant financial pressures on him.

item.title: Trump Claims He Declassified Documents, but His Lawyers Don’t
item.description: Judges this week highlighted the gap between Mr. Trump’s public claims that he declassified everything and his lawyers’ reluctance to repeat that claim in a courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:description: A detailed property inventory of documents and other items seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate.

item.title: Major Covid Holdouts in Asia Drop Border Restrictions
item.description: Hong Kong, Taiwan and Japan have relaxed their pandemic rules, as they look to bolster their economies and play catch-up with much of the world.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Tourists in the Asakusa district of Tokyo earlier this month.

item.title: World Bank Leader, Accused of Climate Denial, Offers a New Response
item.description: David Malpass touched off a furor, including calls for his removal, when he refused to acknowledge that fossil fuels are warming the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated to lead the World Bank in 2019 by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Opening Paul Allen’s Treasure Chest
item.description: It’s been a closely guarded secret which masterworks in the Microsoft co-founder’s collection will be auctioned at Christie’s in November. Here, highlights of a billionaire’s bounty.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin

item.title: Alex Jones Says He’s ‘Done’ Apologizing to Sandy Hook Families
item.description: In testimony in a Connecticut trial to assess the damages done by his Sandy Hook lies, the Infowars fabulist lashed out.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones said that “the First Amendment will prevail” as he left the courthouse in Waterbury, Conn., on Thursday.

item.title: House Passes Police Funding Bills, as Democrats Remain Divided
item.description: Progressive objections to the legislation threatened to sink it at the last moment, prompting a scramble among Democrats that highlighted the party’s divisions over policing.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Stephanie Lai
item.media:description: The House on Thursday passed legislation to increase funding for local police departments, but progressives initially balked at sending money to police departments without stronger accountability measures to address excessive use of force or other misconduct.

item.title: Jury Rules Against Project Veritas in Lawsuit
item.description: The conservative group was found to have violated wiretapping laws and fraudulently misrepresented itself to a Democratic consulting firm, to which it was ordered to pay $120,000.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:description: James O’Keefe, the founder of Project Veritas, calls his employees journalists but has come under fire for their deceptive practices.

item.title: Why New York Is Resorting to Tents to House Surge of Migrants
item.description: With over 10,000 asylum seekers crowding homeless shelters, the city will erect temporary structures to hold new arrivals for their first few days.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:description: South and Central American migrants have arrived so quickly and in such large numbers that the city homeless shelter system has become overwhelmed.

item.title: A.C.L.U. Says Immigration Detention Facility Should Be Shut Down
item.description: The situation at a New Mexico detention facility revives a long-running debate over the government’s reliance on private prisons to house immigrants, many of them seeking asylum.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Living conditions at the Torrance County Detention Facility have been under scrutiny for months.

item.title: Zach Bryan Is Music’s Most Reluctant New Star
item.description: The Navy veteran — who blends folk, rock and country — has had a breakthrough year with his major-label debut, “American Heartbreak.” But fame isn’t what he’s after.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Kristin Braga Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bryan records and releases music at a furious pace. “I have this weird fear of like, if I don’t put this music out, someone 20 years from now isn’t going to be able to hear it,” he said.

item.title: Why Russia Is Losing the War in Ukraine
item.description: A national security expert takes stock of what the U.S. got wrong about Putin — and how Ukraine is gaining momentum, seven months in.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Putin Is Not Liberating My Family. He Is Subjugating Them.
item.description: Starting on Friday, people in four occupied regions of Ukraine will “vote” on whether to become a part of Russia. Here’s what that really means.
item.dc:creator: Sasha Vasilyuk
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in a police station in Kupiansk, Ukraine, depicts a Russian soldier and a woman holding a Soviet flag.

item.title: Giving People Money Is a Great Way to Reduce Poverty
item.description: Dozens of pilot programs and the success of the Child Tax Credit show the merits of a guaranteed income.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: There Is a Way to Solve the Problem of Hyperpartisan Judges
item.description: Expand the federal judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Betrayal and Blackouts in Puerto Rico
item.description: It is our own people who rob and abuse us.
item.dc:creator: Israel Meléndez Ayala
item.media:description: Protesters outside the governor’s mansion La Fortaleza in San Juan, Puerto Rico in July.

item.title: What We Will Miss Most About Roger Federer
item.description: His legacy is not reflected in just his career stats.
item.dc:creator: Michael Steinberger
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: We Document Human Rights Violations. Israel Wants to Silence Us
item.description: If the rest of the world lets this happen, Palestinians will have less recourse for the injustices they face.
item.dc:creator: Shawan Jabarin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The office of Al-Haq, a human rights organization in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

item.title: Every Moment Can’t Be 10 Out of 10
item.description: I’ve come to see the wisdom in not just seeking, but finding, joy in the mundane, in the unremarkable, even in the frankly boring.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wildman

item.title: How to Exercise Safely Outside in the Fall and Winter
item.description: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
item.description: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
item.media:credit: Irina Rozovsky for The New York Times

item.title: A Pesto for Every Pantry and Mood
item.description: Use the Ligurian sauce as a guideline and make tastier sandwiches, soups, pastas, gratins and more.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Jessica Emily Marx for The New York Times

item.title: 高铁上的卫生巾和浸透血水的防护服
item.description: 平均而言，女性一生中有2535天处于经期，常年忍受痛苦和不便，但月经仍被视为一种禁忌甚至耻辱。一场关于高铁上是否应该卖卫生巾的讨论再次凸显出中国社会对女性的忽视和女性争取权益的困境。
item.dc:creator: Zhan Juan
item.media:description: 武汉疫情最严重的时期，被运送到当地医院的卫生巾。

item.title: Ime Udoka, Boston Celtics Coach, Suspended for 2022-23 Season
item.description: The team said Udoka violated unspecified team policies. He led Boston to the N.B.A. finals last season, his first as a head coach.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Celtics Coach Ime Udoka spent nine seasons as an assistant coach in the N.B.A. before Boston hired him as its head coach in June 2021.

item.title: Apple to Sponsor the Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: Apple’s pursuit of an N.F.L. media package has broadened to include a sponsorship of one of TV’s most-watched events.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Lopez performing in the Super Bowl halftime show in 2020. The N.F.L. is offering sponsorship of the event for roughly $50 million, people familiar with the talks said.

item.title: U.K. Government Goes Full Tilt on Tax Cuts and Free-Market Economics
item.description: The new administration’s proposals are a sharp break from the era of Boris Johnson, and they represent a turn toward Thatcherism.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, will be hoping that the measures can engineer at least the start of a solid economic recovery before a general election that must take place by January 2025.

item.title: Saving Whales From Ship Collisions With Warnings and Letter Grades
item.description: Four whales have died near San Francisco this year after ships crashed into them, and scientists hope to drive that number to zero with new technology.
item.dc:creator: Alex Fox
item.media:credit: Dexter Hake for The New York Times

item.title: Can You Get the New Covid Booster and Flu Shot at the Same Time?
item.description: Combining vaccines may be more convenient, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

item.title: What Is Legionnaires’ Disease and How Can I Protect Myself?
item.description: Nearly one out of every 10 people who gets sick with Legionnaires’ dies because of complications from the illness. Here’s what to know about prevention, detection and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Why a Child’s Rude Behavior May Be Good for Development
item.description: The safer children feel, the more they can show their true selves — warts and all — experts say. And that’s good for their development.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Can Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Improve Mental Health?
item.description: On social media, exercises that aim to “tone” one of our body’s longest nerves have been touted as a cure-all for anxiety and other psychological ailments. Here’s what the research says.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Why L.G.B.T.Q. Adults Are More Vulnerable to Heart Disease
item.description: Experts say that a leading cause of death often goes overlooked.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Joan Didion’s Memorial Service Was a Star-Studded Evening
item.description: Among the well-wishers at Joan Didion’s memorial service in New York.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein
item.media:credit: Gus Powell for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
